Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Stellar Mass Content of Galaxy Dark Matter Halos
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stars seem reluctant to form in galaxy dark matter halos. This is a puzzle. To help solve it, the team will study the stars in a vast array of dark matter halos. They will use optical and near-infrared data to measure the mass of the stars in galaxies and also between the galaxies in groups and clusters. The measurements will be used to test theories that claim to have solved the puzzle. Undergraduates will be heavily involved in the research. The PI and his undergraduates will host hands-on events for the public. They will advertise the events at schools in Albany, New York that serve underrepresented groups. The PI will develop learning activities for undergraduates and high-school students and teachers.

The team will study the light from stars in dark matter halos, on the scales of galaxies, groups of galaxies, and clusters of galaxies. Their goals are to (1) measure the relationship between stellar masses and halo masses; and (2) constrain the total baryon fraction in massive dark matter halos.

POR.DRECONTENT:
RUI: Stellar Mass Content of Galaxy Dark Matter Halos

Intellectual Merit

Galaxies, collections of tens to hundreds of billions of stars, are the building blocks of the universe. One of the key goals of modern science is to understand how galaxies formed, and what happens to them over the 14 billion-year history of the universe to change and evolve.

In this project, we study galaxies at the centers of galaxy groups and clusters, regions in space where hundreds and even thousands of galaxies agglomerate because of the gravitational pull of large amounts of unseen dark matter. These "central galaxies" rank among the most massive galaxies in the universe; however, it is not yet known how central galaxies become so massive and how their formation depends on the amount of surrounding dark matter.

This award has supported the Principal Investigator's participation in a new, state-of-the-art survey of the sky called the DESI Legacy Imaging Surveys (Legacy Surveys for short; see https://www.legacysurvey.org). The Legacy Surveys uses the latest generation of ground-based instruments at established astronomical observatories to collect images in the optical portion of the electromagnetic spectrum over more than half of the sky, roughly 20,000 square degrees. The resulting deep imaging is sensitive to the star-light of distant central galaxies, thereby allowing us to investigate their formation pathways.

We use the Legacy Surveys imaging and state-of-the-art analysis techniques to obtain a precise census of the total amount of star-light in a sample of more than five thousand distant central galaxies. We find that central galaxies contain a significant reservoir of stellar mass---up to 50%!---in their faint, outer regions. In addition, we find that galaxies which reside at the centers of more massive dark matter halos tend to contain a higher fraction of their light in these outer regions compared to their bright, central regions. This exciting result suggests that the most massive galaxies most likely formed by cannibalizing the stars from smaller satellite galaxies while the parent dark matter halo was assembling over billions of years.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts portion of this project focused on two key areas: undergraduate (college) students and science teachers.

Over its lifetime, this project provided high-impact research experiences and training for 16 Siena College undergraduate students and one high school student. Among these, nine students, or 53%, have been women and/or minorities, both of whom are traditionally under-represented in academia and in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) private sector.

The students supported by this grant either aspire to (if they have not yet graduated) or are in an impressively diverse and high-impact range of positions, including physics or astronomy graduate school, the STEM private sector, software engineering, high school physics teaching, and medical school.

Several of these students also had tremendous experiential learning experiences because of this award, including traveling to world-class astronomical observatories in Chile and southern Arizona and presenting their work at workshops, collaboration meetings, and national meetings.

In addition, this grant sponsored two Astronomy-at-the-Frontier workshops (in 2017 and 2020) for grades 8-12 science teachers. These workshops provided information and training with hands-on, high-impact activities on a wide range of modern topics in astronomy, including planets beyond our solar system, the formation of the universe, and the life cycle of stars. These kinds of training experiences are especially valuable because they can help inform a much larger and diverse group of students about important ideas in science and and hopefully inspire them to pursue science and engineering in college and beyond.
